FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 9, 1934.

One of two things ought instantly to be done.
Either the business manager of last year should be
called in and given a chance to exonerate himself (or
vice versa); or else the president of the Student Activities Council should retract all remarks made relative to the matter and show that there is no money
missing. Anything short of one of these steps is an
injustice to the students, who pay the bills, and to last
year's Hullabaloo staff, which dispensed the money.
At this juncture we can't resist kicking the dead
horse again. Of course, the whole trouble is with
the delinquency of the Student Activities Council.
Dean Berry may be perfectly sure that the Council is
the most useful body on the campus, but sooner or
later he must realize that the Council realizes that he
is the only one who should be running things. The
organization is too unwieldy and fritters away its
time and the students' money. Find logic, if you
can, in the fact that the Council, openly claimed to be
in charge of activities, hasn't even met for practically
two months. And that with the activities in the most
precarious state they've been in for years.
The answer is clear enough: everybody knows
that the Dean is running things. And 'most everyone
will admit that a single responsible controller is, an
advantage. But why preserve the farce of a Council? And why doesn't the Dean go all the way and
undertake to clear up the matter of the $600 without
further ado? These questions are legitimate and any
straight-thinking person rather hopes for positive
response to them.

And Now To Mark Time

MORE ON HIGHER EDUCATION
A REPLY TO ERIC GOLDMAN
On the face of it, Eric, your recent flip in THE
NEWS-LETTER was a calm presentation of a noble
and highly reasonable point of view—a most praiseworthy one, in fact. But underneath it all, one sensed
the simmering, indeed seething, of moral indignation.
Your whole article, if I am not mistaken, was a morally indignant plea for more moral indignation, a plea
for men who could get hot under the collar at the
sight of human suffering and could utilize their accumulated stores of knowledge and culture for the
realization of a vision guaranteed to do away with
that suffering. The system of education at Hopkins,
you potherously declared, does not and cannot turn
out such men. Ergo, the system of education at Hopkins is a failure.
Like all moral indignants, your vision is blurred
when you choke with indignation. You are prone
to dogmatism of an adolescent or puerile (if that
is less insulting) character. You are convinced of the
cogency of a solution and you flaunt that solution in
the face of the world as the one and only. There is
no other god but a vision, and moral indignation is its
prophet. Far be it from me to belittle moral indignation or firm convictions. I thank God I can still
become morally indignant, and remember praying in
the early years of my adolescence for convictions, for
an integrating principle that would be my salvation.
But when you come along and propose as the only
solution to our moral, social and intellectual problems
a vision, a wraith rising out of the boiling cauldronof
moral indignation, I call it narrow dogmatism, if not
downright superstition. You throw out the scientific
method, you flippantly dispose of Stravinsky, Picasso,
France and Lucretius, or what they stand for, and
set up a wrath-bound Jehovah, who is dull and blind,
as judge.
o—o
No, Eric, higher education is a failure for quite
other reasons. You will agree that, first of all, there
are two factors in the process—the education and the

educated. If the latter are a nonentity, there can't be
any reaction, any results. So we posit intelligent
people. Now the object of education is to make intelligent people, no, not charming, but noble. And
you will understand what I mean, when I explain the
process by which education can in most cases make
intelligent people noble.
The object, or more clearly, the effect of learning
and culture is to create and satisfy emotions. Each
new fact, each intellectual acquaintance, each successive horizon either satisfies an emotion or creates a
new one. A venture into vector analysis, a deep appreciation of Sisley's shimmering 'scapes, or the recognition of beauty with Keats—all these satisfy an
emotion or desire and possibly create one. And the
object of education is to provide us with these experiences or show us how to get to them. And the educator is part of the same purpose. Now these emotions, once experienced, do not leave us as we were.
Our psyche is touched, affected, molded and enlarged.
And I, for one, presume for the better. In general,
a man who has probed the springs of a varied and intelligent emotional experience cannot help but be more
understanding in his judgment, more noble in his
decisions. He has known good and evil, sympathizes
with them, and becomes possessed of a mature noble
wisdom that changes worlds and creates them. It
seems, Eric, that after all we both want men of vision.
But I cannot "see" men whose vision is evolved out
of some frenetic hypnosis. I do not think the froth
of moral indignation is a true enough substance to
build visions on. The trouble with men of vision of
the type you pray for is that the more vision they have,
the less men they are.
o—o
Kemler was right. He is a hopeful specimen. He
feels the need of a broader experience, of a wider
knowledge of what men have achieved and hoped for.
He hasn't found it at the Hopkins.
C. B. HIRSCHFELD.

GLENN FRANK: A PORTRAYAL

secured to reprint the following excerpts from the article, "Glenn'Frank

That the quality of Hollywood
cinematic productions is bound to
improve as a result of the influx of
new blood from abroad, was asserted by Herman G. Weinberg, director of the Little Theatre, speaking
before the Johns Hopkins Playshop
last Tuesday evening on the subject
of "Recent Tendencies in the Cinema".
Germany, which was the former
center of the art film, has completely
disappeared from the motion picture
world, the speaker declared, and its
best directors and actors are now to
be found in England, France and
Hollywood. As an example, Mr.
Weinberg mentioned Pabst, the
noted director of "Kameradschaft",
who is now directing a picture starring Richard Barthelmess after rejecting Ruth Chatterton for his first
assignment.

To Speak Here

But if Mr. Thomas is a moralist
and a philosopher, he is likewise a
man of action. A great strike was
in progress at Passaic, New Jersey.
Norman Thomas appeared on the
scene to champion the cause of the
workers. As he addressed a great
mass meeting of the strikers, the
lights were suddenly shut off and
attempts were made to break up the
gathering. But the Socialist crusader held the stage as under the
flickering light of a candle he proceeded to read the Constitution of
the United States with its provisions
for the right to peaceful assembly
and petition.
Norman Thomas is one of the
speakers who has been secured to
address the Sixth Annual Intercollegiate Conference to be held in

Levering Hall on March 2 and 3
under the sponsorship of the Johns
Hopkins Liberal Club and the
Goucher College L. I. D. chapter.
The convention which is to hear
prominent speakers discuss the
question of "War and the Student",
is expected to attract delegates from
the colleges and universities of
Maryland, District of Columbia,
Pennsylvania, New York, and some
of the Southern states.
Born In Ohio

Mr. Thomas was born in Marion,
Ohio, in 1884, and as young boy,
delivered the paper that was then
edited by Warren G. Harding.
After making a brilliant record at
Bucknell, Princeton, and Union
Theological Seminary, he engaged in
social service work in New York
City, where he also held a pulpit. In
1917, Mr. Thomas resigned from
the ministry, joined the Socialist
Party, and attempted to keep this
country out of the war.

CENTRE

Criticizes Censorship

Censorship came in for criticism
as Mr. Weinberg warned that many
of the most unusual of the European
films would be denied to American
audiences as the result of censorial
rulings. The Russian film, "Bed
and Sofa", was rejected by the New
York censor because of its daring
treatment of sex.
According to Mr. Weinberg,"Bed
and Sofa" is the story of a Russian
couple, who, because of crowded living conditions are compelled to live
in one room. Being unable to find
any other living quarters, a friend
of the husband moves in and occupies the sofa. Then the husband is
called away to Germany on business.
The occupant of the sofa moves into
the bed. When the husband returns,
his friend goes back to his sofa.
Discusses Seur-Realists

The speaker also discussed the
Seur-realists, a French group who
have been creating highly fantastic,
introspective pictures that are above
realism. One of their productions,
"Blood of a Poet" by Jean Cocteau,
is now playing in New York City.
Mr. Weinberg's lecture was followed by a one-act play, "Tumble
Weed", written by Pearl Head Latcham and directed by Myra Lehr.
The cast of the play included R.
Reardon Fusselbaugh, Samuel Selsky, Virginia Latcham, Alfred
Greenwood, and Leroy Shuger.
Dr. Fagin, director of the Playshop, announced that "Hedda Gabler" by Henrik Ibsen has been selected as the dramatic group's second major production of the year.
Five performances of the play will
be given at the Homewood Theatre
the week of February 20.

Illness Of Johnson
Temporarily Halts
Frosh-Soph Plans
Due to the illness of Meade
Johnson, president of the sophomore class, plans for the combined
dance and a condensed Banquet season have been temporarily halted.
Ballots will be distributed in the
post-office boxes of the members of
the freshman and sophomore classes.
These ballots will enable the officers
of the classes to determine definitely
the program for the planned affairs.
All freshmen and sophomores are
urged to cooperate by filling out the
ballots and returning them as soon
as possible.

FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 9, 1934.

One of two things ought instantly to be done.
Either the business manager of last year should be
called in and given a chance to exonerate himself (or
vice versa); or else the president of the Student Activities Council should retract all remarks made relative to the matter and show that there is no money
missing. Anything short of one of these steps is an
injustice to the students, who pay the bills, and to last
year's Hullabaloo staff, which dispensed the money.
At this juncture we can't resist kicking the dead
horse again. Of course, the whole trouble is with
the delinquency of the Student Activities Council.
Dean Berry may be perfectly sure that the Council is
the most useful body on the campus, but sooner or
later he must realize that the Council realizes that he
is the only one who should be running things. The
organization is too unwieldy and fritters away its
time and the students' money. Find logic, if you
can, in the fact that the Council, openly claimed to be
in charge of activities, hasn't even met for practically
two months. And that with the activities in the most
precarious state they've been in for years.
The answer is clear enough: everybody knows
that the Dean is running things. And 'most everyone
will admit that a single responsible controller is, an
advantage. But why preserve the farce of a Council? And why doesn't the Dean go all the way and
undertake to clear up the matter of the $600 without
further ado? These questions are legitimate and any
straight-thinking person rather hopes for positive
response to them.

And Now To Mark Time

MORE ON HIGHER EDUCATION
A REPLY TO ERIC GOLDMAN
On the face of it, Eric, your recent flip in THE
NEWS-LETTER was a calm presentation of a noble
and highly reasonable point of view—a most praiseworthy one, in fact. But underneath it all, one sensed
the simmering, indeed seething, of moral indignation.
Your whole article, if I am not mistaken, was a morally indignant plea for more moral indignation, a plea
for men who could get hot under the collar at the
sight of human suffering and could utilize their accumulated stores of knowledge and culture for the
realization of a vision guaranteed to do away with
that suffering. The system of education at Hopkins,
you potherously declared, does not and cannot turn
out such men. Ergo, the system of education at Hopkins is a failure.
Like all moral indignants, your vision is blurred
when you choke with indignation. You are prone
to dogmatism of an adolescent or puerile (if that
is less insulting) character. You are convinced of the
cogency of a solution and you flaunt that solution in
the face of the world as the one and only. There is
no other god but a vision, and moral indignation is its
prophet. Far be it from me to belittle moral indignation or firm convictions. I thank God I can still
become morally indignant, and remember praying in
the early years of my adolescence for convictions, for
an integrating principle that would be my salvation.
But when you come along and propose as the only
solution to our moral, social and intellectual problems
a vision, a wraith rising out of the boiling cauldronof
moral indignation, I call it narrow dogmatism, if not
downright superstition. You throw out the scientific
method, you flippantly dispose of Stravinsky, Picasso,
France and Lucretius, or what they stand for, and
set up a wrath-bound Jehovah, who is dull and blind,
as judge.
o—o
No, Eric, higher education is a failure for quite
other reasons. You will agree that, first of all, there
are two factors in the process—the education and the

educated. If the latter are a nonentity, there can't be
any reaction, any results. So we posit intelligent
people. Now the object of education is to make intelligent people, no, not charming, but noble. And
you will understand what I mean, when I explain the
process by which education can in most cases make
intelligent people noble.
The object, or more clearly, the effect of learning
and culture is to create and satisfy emotions. Each
new fact, each intellectual acquaintance, each successive horizon either satisfies an emotion or creates a
new one. A venture into vector analysis, a deep appreciation of Sisley's shimmering 'scapes, or the recognition of beauty with Keats—all these satisfy an
emotion or desire and possibly create one. And the
object of education is to provide us with these experiences or show us how to get to them. And the educator is part of the same purpose. Now these emotions, once experienced, do not leave us as we were.
Our psyche is touched, affected, molded and enlarged.
And I, for one, presume for the better. In general,
a man who has probed the springs of a varied and intelligent emotional experience cannot help but be more
understanding in his judgment, more noble in his
decisions. He has known good and evil, sympathizes
with them, and becomes possessed of a mature noble
wisdom that changes worlds and creates them. It
seems, Eric, that after all we both want men of vision.
But I cannot "see" men whose vision is evolved out
of some frenetic hypnosis. I do not think the froth
of moral indignation is a true enough substance to
build visions on. The trouble with men of vision of
the type you pray for is that the more vision they have,
the less men they are.
o—o
Kemler was right. He is a hopeful specimen. He
feels the need of a broader experience, of a wider
knowledge of what men have achieved and hoped for.
He hasn't found it at the Hopkins.
C. B. HIRSCHFELD.

That the quality of Hollywood
cinematic productions is bound to
improve as a result of the influx of
new blood from abroad, was asserted by Herman G. Weinberg, director of the Little Theatre, speaking
before the Johns Hopkins Playshop
last Tuesday evening on the subject
of "Recent Tendencies in the Cinema".
Germany, which was the former
center of the art film, has completely
disappeared from the motion picture
world, the speaker declared, and its
best directors and actors are now to
be found in England, France and
Hollywood. As an example, Mr.
Weinberg mentioned Pabst, the
noted director of "Kameradschaft",
who is now directing a picture starring Richard Barthelmess after rejecting Ruth Chatterton for his first
assignment.

To Speak Here

But if Mr. Thomas is a moralist
and a philosopher, he is likewise a
man of action. A great strike was
in progress at Passaic, New Jersey.
Norman Thomas appeared on the
scene to champion the cause of the
workers. As he addressed a great
mass meeting of the strikers, the
lights were suddenly shut off and
attempts were made to break up the
gathering. But the Socialist crusader held the stage as under the
flickering light of a candle he proceeded to read the Constitution of
the United States with its provisions
for the right to peaceful assembly
and petition.
Norman Thomas is one of the
speakers who has been secured to
address the Sixth Annual Intercollegiate Conference to be held in

Levering Hall on March 2 and 3
under the sponsorship of the Johns
Hopkins Liberal Club and the
Goucher College L. I. D. chapter.
The convention which is to hear
prominent speakers discuss the
question of "War and the Student",
is expected to attract delegates from
the colleges and universities of
Maryland, District of Columbia,
Pennsylvania, New York, and some
of the Southern states.
Born In Ohio

Mr. Thomas was born in Marion,
Ohio, in 1884, and as young boy,
delivered the paper that was then
edited by Warren G. Harding.
After making a brilliant record at
Bucknell, Princeton, and Union
Theological Seminary, he engaged in
social service work in New York
City, where he also held a pulpit. In
1917, Mr. Thomas resigned from
the ministry, joined the Socialist
Party, and attempted to keep this
country out of the war.

SPORTS

CENTRE

Criticizes Censorship

Censorship came in for criticism
as Mr. Weinberg warned that many
of the most unusual of the European
films would be denied to American
audiences as the result of censorial
rulings. The Russian film, "Bed
and Sofa", was rejected by the New
York censor because of its daring
treatment of sex.
According to Mr. Weinberg,"Bed
and Sofa" is the story of a Russian
couple, who, because of crowded living conditions are compelled to live
in one room. Being unable to find
any other living quarters, a friend
of the husband moves in and occupies the sofa. Then the husband is
called away to Germany on business.
The occupant of the sofa moves into
the bed. When the husband returns,
his friend goes back to his sofa.
Discusses Seur-Realists

The speaker also discussed the
Seur-realists, a French group who
have been creating highly fantastic,
introspective pictures that are above
realism. One of their productions,
"Blood of a Poet" by Jean Cocteau,
is now playing in New York City.
Mr. Weinberg's lecture was followed by a one-act play, "Tumble
Weed", written by Pearl Head Latcham and directed by Myra Lehr.
The cast of the play included R.
Reardon Fusselbaugh, Samuel Selsky, Virginia Latcham, Alfred
Greenwood, and Leroy Shuger.
Dr. Fagin, director of the Playshop, announced that "Hedda Gabler" by Henrik Ibsen has been selected as the dramatic group's second major production of the year.
Five performances of the play will
be given at the Homewood Theatre
the week of February 20.

Illness Of Johnson
Temporarily Halts
Frosh-Soph Plans
Due to the illness of Meade
Johnson, president of the sophomore class, plans for the combined
dance and a condensed Banquet season have been temporarily halted.
Ballots will be distributed in the
post-office boxes of the members of
the freshman and sophomore classes.
These ballots will enable the officers
of the classes to determine definitely
the program for the planned affairs.
All freshmen and sophomores are
urged to cooperate by filling out the
ballots and returning them as soon
as possible.
